annotation.TEXT: This is among one of my favorite stages in the game, at least in terms of overall look and mechanic potential. The main gimmick of this stage are black holes, which draw in both your own and the enemy's projectiles. The same thing sort of applies to the Saturn enemies found here, which have their own gravitational pull.

The 2nd place stage certainly has some nice aesthetics to it, as you can probably tell. The custom enemies are definitely the highlight of this place, with almost all of them being nicely rendered from Mario to Mega Man style (the Koopas could use some work though, in my opinion).

The 4th place level's gimmick involves Guts Man's lift platforms, though mainly used in a pseudo auto-scroller type fashion (with a few vertical sections thrown in as well). Personally, I've never been a big fan of this type of gimmick, but this stage actually manages to pull it off relatively well. The overall layout isn't too difficult to get the hang of, the vertical sections give you enough space to see what you're supposed to drop down to next (which is sadly a rare case when it comes to these games, at least from my experience).

My only major gripe with this level is the jump you need to make to this falling lift. The platform starts moving the instant it touches the rails, which means you need to make an extremely precise jump (or use Rush Jet) to land on it. If you're even a second too late, you'll miss the lift by a few pixels.

And without further ado, here we have the overall winner of the contest: RedBlupi's "Glass Man" stage. Now then, I might not agree with the placement on some of the other levels (specifically, I think "Hard to See Land" should have been in Tier 2 or maybe even Tier 1, for that matter), but as far as this level goes? It definitely deserves 1st place, for one simple reason: It's the only submitted stage in the entire game that actually feels like a Mega Man level (in terms of design, length, enemy placement, etc).

Gravity Man is a bit of a gimmick fight, in that you mainly have to rely on the Saturn enemies to pull your shots up towards him. Granted, he does get absolutely destroyed by a certain weapon, but for now, I'll be fighting him the intended way.

Upcoming transition effect again, though this time not due to a death in-game, but rather in recording. I have no idea what caused this error, but everything beyond this point basically became unusable (mostly due to audio weirdness).

It took a while, but we're finally here: Tier 5, the best levels in the contest. Notably, while there's 4 entries here, there's a distinct lack of boss for this section (then again, the overall winning stage already has a well designed boss - but I'll get to that soon enough).

With that being said however, I'm in agreement with Cheez8's overall thoughts on this stage: While it's certainly a cute idea, the charm wears off pretty fast. For me, it's mostly due to the length of this stage. It's way too long for its own good (for reference, the average Mega Man stage lasts roughly 25 or so screens, while I estimate this one to be around 60 screens - just by counting them off manually).

Apparently, this glitch is due to bad placement of transitions. As far as I remember, this instance in particular has been an issue since the first release of this game (And before anyone asks: As of writing this, Ver 1.6 - the one I'm using - is indeed the latest version).

Glass Man is a pretty fun (if rather easy) boss. His main attacks involve glass panels, which can push you back if you're hit by them. However, the only really threatening move he has is his glass bubble, which can (usually) be avoided by hugging either the left or right corner of the room. Beyond that, you can actually shatter his glass panels with the Gemini Laser - which is supposed to be his weakness...but in actuality, he takes more damage from the buster.

Incoming stupid looking death. Maybe it's just me, but if there's one other problem I have with this stage, it's most of the jumps. Almost all of these pits seem pretty wide (and the slight elevation of the other side doesn't really help much).

In case you're having a hard time seeing it, the Gemini Laser actually got stuck in the corner of the platforms to the left (it doesn't happen too often in this game, but when it does, it can be really annoying).

There's a decent amount of switch flipping (or in this case, destroying) puzzles in the first half of this stage, while the second half mainly focuses on using the black holes in conjunction with certain enemies. This is where one of the problems of the stage lies, as some of the enemy layouts can be downright annoying to deal with (in those regards, there's a few particular Sniper Joes that don't seem worth it to take on directly, making it better to just tank a hit and bypass them).

With all that being said, Friendly Dictator still gets points in my book for using the most (and quite possibly, the only) accurate 8-bit rendition of "Take on Me." Seriously people, stop using GXSCC and claiming that it's 8-bit.
